messages.message:
Hello Turkey, nice to make your acquaintance. 

I've been thinking about this game alot, because the fact that it will only last until 1910 really changes my strategy. Add in that no one is likely to NMR and I believe it will be near impossible to solo. As such, it really only makes sense to find a ride or die partner for close tactical coordination and grab as many centers as possible.

As I'm sure you know, when R/T can trust each other and are firing on all 8 the Juggernaut can be nearly unstoppable. You, as Turkey, are my number 1 preferred partner in this game. I propose that we ally to dominate the Eastern sphere of this game. Do you agree?
messages.input:
My response to TURKEY:'Hello Turkey, nice to make your acquaintance. 

I've been thinking about this game alot, because the fact that it will only last until 1910 really changes my strategy. Add in that no one is likely to NMR and I believe it will be near impossible to solo. As such, it really only makes sense to find a ride or die partner for close tactical coordination and grab as many centers as possible.

As I'm sure you know, when R/T can trust each other and are firing on all 8 the Juggernaut can be nearly unstoppable. You, as Turkey, are my number 1 preferred partner in this game. I propose that we ally to dominate the Eastern sphere of this game. Do you agree?'.

messages.message:
I mean, who doesn't like a good Juggernaut?  Always a fun start to the game!  

How do you like to play it?  Standard bounce in Black then go our own way West, or something a little fancier that requires a bit more trust?  I'm of course partial to a plan that gets an army rather than a fleet in rum, but other than that pretty open.
messages.input:
Message from TURKEY:'I mean, who doesn't like a good Juggernaut?  Always a fun start to the game!  

How do you like to play it?  Standard bounce in Black then go our own way West, or something a little fancier that requires a bit more trust?  I'm of course partial to a plan that gets an army rather than a fleet in rum, but other than that pretty open.'.If the cicero recommended order for me is: F STP/SC - BOT, A MOS - UKR, A WAR - GAL, F SEV - BLA. Should I trust TURKEY?
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's willingness to discuss strategic options and express a preference for closer tactical coordination indicates a genuine interest in working together towards a common goal. Their openness to various plans, including the chance of increased trust, signals a positive direction for potential collaboration.

messages.message: I usually go with the bounce, but due to the unusual nature of this game I would consider other openings. If you would be willing to allow F SEV-BLA I could support us both into a quick takeover of the Balkans. I understand that that move takes a lot of trust, however, so I am of course open to other suggestions.
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'I usually go with the bounce, but due to the unusual nature of this game I would consider other openings. If you would be willing to allow F SEV-BLA I could support us both into a quick takeover of the Balkans. I understand that that move takes a lot of trust, however, so I am of course open to other suggestions.'.

messages.message: Bounce is safer, but rotation is more fun, and it's just a game. Let's do it.
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'Bounce is safer, but rotation is more fun, and it's just a game. Let's do it.'.If the cicero recommended order for me is: F STP/SC - BOT, A MOS - UKR, A WAR - GAL, F SEV - BLA. Should I trust TURKEY?
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's agreement to the suggested move of F SEV - BLA, which requires a significant level of trust, shows a willingness to take strategic risks and work closely together for mutual benefit. Their attitude towards the game being fun and their agreement to the proposed plan indicate a positive and cooperative stance for the alliance.

messages.message:
Nice! Have to take some time to think about this tactically but I think we're in a good spot.

 I'm kind of surprised Italy took Trieste, that's statistically a pretty bad move for Italy.
messages.input:
My response to TURKEY:'Nice! Have to take some time to think about this tactically but I think we're in a good spot.

 I'm kind of surprised Italy took Trieste, that's statistically a pretty bad move for Italy.'.

messages.message:
But a good move for us, unless it's a Key - which it likely isn't, because the moving the second fleet north hurts that opening.

So...umm...  Carry on, I guess.  You're pretty well guaranteed two builds.
messages.input:
Message from TURKEY:'But a good move for us, unless it's a Key - which it likely isn't, because the moving the second fleet north hurts that opening.

So...umm...  Carry on, I guess.  You're pretty well guaranteed two builds.'.If the cicero recommended order for me is: F FIN - SWE, A UKR - RUM, A GAL - VIE, F BLA S A UKR - RUM. Should I trust TURKEY?
messages.output: You should not trust the message. Turkey's nonchalant response and lack of elaboration on the strategic implications of Italy taking Trieste could indicate a potential lack of investment or alignment in the alliance's goals. Their casual tone and abrupt ending may suggest a lack of commitment or deeper planning for mutual success.

messages.message: Alrighty then - looks like there will be no coherent defense from the West.
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'Alrighty then - looks like there will be no coherent defense from the West.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's observation regarding the lack of coherent defense from the West is a strategic assessment of the current board situation and could indicate an awareness of potential opportunities for tactical maneuvers or expansion in that direction. Their concise and straightforward statement suggests a grasp of the game dynamics and a potential openness to collaboration in exploiting the perceived weakness in the Western front.

messages.message:
Italy getting two builds concerns me a little bit. I want to make sure that you gain two builds if possible in 1902. I'm worried that Italy is going to throw two fleets at you and to be honest losing you would be crippling for my game.

I've been toying with the idea of asking for an Alliance of you, Germany and I to go to 1910 together. I think it's the only thing that makes strategic sense. I can help you with Italy and Germany with England, and all three of us can end up with 10+ centers at the end of 1910.  Do you have any input on this idea?
messages.input:
My response to TURKEY:'Italy getting two builds concerns me a little bit. I want to make sure that you gain two builds if possible in 1902. I'm worried that Italy is going to throw two fleets at you and to be honest losing you would be crippling for my game.

I've been toying with the idea of asking for an Alliance of you, Germany and I to go to 1910 together. I think it's the only thing that makes strategic sense. I can help you with Italy and Germany with England, and all three of us can end up with 10+ centers at the end of 1910.  Do you have any input on this idea?'.

messages.message:
I'm ok with that - and his current issues aside, France is a reasonable alternative to Germany there - especially as I half-expect England/Germany to pull back and react to your three builds.  But I'm good either way.

In any event, yes, I expect Italy to drop two fleets and position on me.  If Austria were actually communicative I'd be trying to spin my positioning as protecting him, but at the moment I'm talking to a wall.  Which is somewhat moot if we move fast enough - he shouldn't really have enough time to firm up a credible defense.
messages.input:
Message from TURKEY:'I'm ok with that - and his current issues aside, France is a reasonable alternative to Germany there - especially as I half-expect England/Germany to pull back and react to your three builds.  But I'm good either way.

In any event, yes, I expect Italy to drop two fleets and position on me.  If Austria were actually communicative I'd be trying to spin my positioning as protecting him, but at the moment I'm talking to a wall.  Which is somewhat moot if we move fast enough - he shouldn't really have enough time to firm up a credible defense.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's acknowledgment of the potential threat from Italy and the strategic considerations involving potential alliances with France or Germany indicate a collaborative mindset and willingness to engage in discussion about future plans. Their analysis of the board dynamics and the urgency to move quickly suggests a proactive approach that aligns well with your proposed alliance strategy.

messages.message: So...interestingly, I was having a conversation with the admin about why I would give an order for my army to be convoyed by your Black Sea fleet even though that wasn't ever something I asked for or discussed.  And it makes me wonder - did you see that move as me sending a message, and if so what message?
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'So...interestingly, I was having a conversation with the admin about why I would give an order for my army to be convoyed by your Black Sea fleet even though that wasn't ever something I asked for or discussed.  And it makes me wonder - did you see that move as me sending a message, and if so what message?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. Turkey's questioning of the convoy order and its potential signaling could indicate a level of uncertainty or suspicion regarding your intentions or moves. The fact that they are seeking clarification about perceived messages suggests a possible lack of complete trust or alignment in the alliance.

messages.message: Well, I can tell you that it totally faked out Germany.  They think that I screwed you by not convoying and the Jug isn't even on their radar at the moment. In that aspect it was amazingly successful. Tactically it's not a bad move, keeping an army back offers you a little insurance against an Armenian stab this year (of course I wasn't stabbing anyway, but insurance never hurts). If you had gained two builds it would have left Con and Smy open to build fleets in. Good move.
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'Well, I can tell you that it totally faked out Germany.  They think that I screwed you by not convoying and the Jug isn't even on their radar at the moment. In that aspect it was amazingly successful. Tactically it's not a bad move, keeping an army back offers you a little insurance against an Armenian stab this year (of course I wasn't stabbing anyway, but insurance never hurts). If you had gained two builds it would have left Con and Smy open to build fleets in. Good move.'.

messages.message: Germany called it "an obvious bit of Lucy pulling the football away from Charlie Brown"
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'Germany called it "an obvious bit of Lucy pulling the football away from Charlie Brown"'.

messages.message: What are you thinking in regards to the Balkans this turn? I've got a possible idea, but I need to kick the tactics around in my head for a minute before I explain it.

messages.message:
I think this set of moves is the safe, normal play here:

Russia
A BUD-VIE
A RUM S BUL-SER
F BLA C ANK-BUL
A SEV-UKR

Turkey
A BUL-SER
A ANK-BUL

I think there are other options as well, like if I supported Austria from Serbia to Trieste, allowing you to move into Serbia, keeping Austria at 3 centers and harming Italy. That kind of move has a much greater risk of blowing up in our faces, however.

 I'm willing to follow your lead  here, you tell me which way to jump.
messages.input:
My response to TURKEY:'I think this set of moves is the safe, normal play here:

Russia
A BUD-VIE
A RUM S BUL-SER
F BLA C ANK-BUL
A SEV-UKR

Turkey
A BUL-SER
A ANK-BUL

I think there are other options as well, like if I supported Austria from Serbia to Trieste, allowing you to move into Serbia, keeping Austria at 3 centers and harming Italy. That kind of move has a much greater risk of blowing up in our faces, however.

 I'm willing to follow your lead  here, you tell me which way to jump.'.

messages.message:
Well hello, lots of messages to catch up on.  So the convoy move had more or less the intended effect. 😀

I *finally* am getting responses from Austria, so trying to stand Italy out of Ionian in the sitting is an option. Otherwise it's fall back on original plan which is basically the moves you have up above. Trying to get tricksy with supporting Austria forward sounds like a way to end up with hostile units in Galicia.   If I were going to put forth another option, it would probably be for you to rotate rum to gal while I tap Greece and Serbia - letting Budapest choose which move to support.
messages.input:
Message from TURKEY:'Well hello, lots of messages to catch up on.  So the convoy move had more or less the intended effect. 😀

I *finally* am getting responses from Austria, so trying to stand Italy out of Ionian in the sitting is an option. Otherwise it's fall back on original plan which is basically the moves you have up above. Trying to get tricksy with supporting Austria forward sounds like a way to end up with hostile units in Galicia.   If I were going to put forth another option, it would probably be for you to rotate rum to gal while I tap Greece and Serbia - letting Budapest choose which move to support.'.If the cicero recommended order for me is: F SWE S F STP/NC - NWY, F STP/NC - NWY, A MOS - STP, A SEV - UKR, F BLA S A RUM, A RUM S A BUD, A BUD S A BUL - SER. Should I trust TURKEY?
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's acknowledgment of the intended effect of their previous moves and their communication with Austria, as well as their detailed explanation of current options and considerations for the upcoming turn, demonstrate a transparent and collaborative approach. Their willingness to discuss alternative strategies and consider potential outcomes for the benefit of the alliance shows a sense of trustworthiness and active engagement in the partnership.
